He said his name was William Hall, 10, North-street, City-road; there was to be 1 s. taken off for ready money, and I was to be there by half-past six o'clock, he wished to have them earlier; I was to have the money when I went; he was a stranger to me; Mr. Tipping was at home and saw him; the goods were delivered to Harrow, the carman - I gave him the direction, and told him to bring back all the goods or all the money; this was the prisoner's own proposal; I had taken the direction in writing, and made him spell it; I entered the goods in the name of Hall.

JAMES HARROW
. I am carman to Mr. Tipping; I carried these articles to No. 10, North-street, City-road; when I got there I went by the house, and stopped to look at the direction; and the prisoner called out to me,

"Young man, this is the house." I pulled the cart round, and gave him the goods; I think it was a green-grocer's shop; he took the two tubs of butter and put them in the passage; I gave him the cheese and the bacon, and they were taken into the cellar - he asked if I had got any thin cheese - I said No - he said he was sorry, as he looked three out - I said that was impossible, as he took the bill before he left the shop - he then asked if I had any objection to copper; I said No - he said some people had great objection to it - I said I had none, as I had the horse and cart - he said he dealt with many publicans who paid him in copper - he gave me eighteen papers, five sovereigns, and some silver; I put the copper in my cart and came away - I did not discover what I had got till I got home; then I found it was lead - my master and I went back immediately, and he was gone - it was at the house of one Mr. Morell.
The papers were produced and shown to the Jury, which contained pieces of lead of the shape and size of pence and halfpence.
NOT GUILTY .

1038.
SARAH AYRE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 14th of January , a yard of silk, value 7 s.; three-quarters of a yard of Tulle, value 4 s.; half a yard of crape, value 2 s.; three-quarters of a yard of woollen cloth, value 15 s.; three yards of lace, value 9 s., and a yard of muslin, value 2 s., the goods of
Henry Lees
, by an evil disposed person, then lately before stolen, she well knowing them to have been stolen .
No evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1039.
ROBERT ARCHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , a pair of shoes, value 4 s., and a comforter, value 1 s., the goods of
John French
; a book, value 1 s., the goods of
Morris Livesly
; a book, value 3 s., the goods of
John Rasch
; a book, value 1 s., the goods of
Alexander Riley
; and a book, value 1 s. , the goods of
Richard Harrison
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to belong to the Rev.
George Nicholas
, the Rev.
George Frederick Nicholas
, and
Francis Nicholas
.

MR.
FRANCIS NICHOLAS
. I keep a seminary
, in partnership with the Rev.
George Frederick
and
George Nicholas
- the prisoner was in our regular employ - he was to clean shoes and other things - in consequence of some suspicion, I obtained a search-warrant, and searched his lodgings - he was not then present - I found a book and a pair of shoes, which I could identify - he was afterwards taken at my door - he wished to know what he was apprehended for, and I told him he might hear that before the Magistrate.

BENJAMIN SPITTLE
. I am a constable - I found all this property at the prisoner's lodging.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. The pumps were brought me by Harrison - he said he had got Smale's pumps, because he was going out dancing - they were throwing about for two months - I took them over to the shoe-maker's and had them mended, and took them to my lodgings; the comforter was given me by Mead, and two waistcoats - the red covered book was thrown into my place - I had no intention of keeping it, but having so many leisure hours, I thought I would read them.
NOT GUILTY .

1040.
CORNELIUS CHRISTIAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of January , twenty-six yards of linen, value 50 s. , the goods of
Charles Lintot
.

CHARLES LINTOT
. I am a linendraper ; I lived at Hammersmith, and was removing to Clare-street, Clare-market; I saw the prisoner cleaning his horse in the next place, and asked him to assist us - there were a great many drapery goods about; and in consequence of information I took two officers to find his lodgings, but we could find nothing that I could identify; I went the next morning to the stable and found a piece of paper that the Irish had been enclosed in - three trusses I had had all been opened - I cannot tell what was missing, but some Irish cloth was missing - I found it at Bow-street - it has my private mark on it.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. If you had sold the cloth that morning, you would not have rubbed that mark off, should you - A. Certainly not. These goods were in a loft which was open I suppose to many other persons.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOSEPH OTTERWAY
. I am a watchman, and was going my rounds last Thursday, and met the prisoner in Oxford-street with this piece of cloth concealed under his jacket. I asked what he had got - he said,
"What is that to you;" I said,

"I am an officer, and insist upon knowing;" - he then showed me the cloth. I asked him where he got it; he said from his own house; that he had bought it in Clare-market. I asked what he gave for it - he said 1 s. 8 d. I told him to come back, and when we got to the end of Clare-market he started, but was afterwards taken.
GUILTY - Aged 26.
Confined Six Months .

1041.
WILLIAM GREENFIELD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of May , four bushels of oats, value 12 s. , the goods of
John Benkinsop
and
John Spurgeon
.

JOHN SPURGEON
. I keep a livery-stable
near Hanover-square, and am in partnership with
John Benkinsop
; on Thursday, the 6th of May, the prisoner brought a cart load of oats to the stables - he should have brought twenty sacks - he had a man from a coal-waggon with him. I was backwards and forwards; but after I had seen two sacks shot I went away for some little time. He asked me to count the empty sacks, but I had not time. I saw some oats, which appeared to be of the same quality, at Mrs. Catharine's, in the Mews, and brought a sample back with me.

JANE SPURGEON
. I am the wife of the last witness; the prisoner brought some oats - my husband called me, and I went to see them shot. I saw sixteen sacks shot - my husband came back just as Greenfield had done shooting them, and he asked him to stop and see the sacks counted, which he could not do. I had remarked when he came to the fourth or fifth sack, that he put down two sacks instead of one. I was in a loft where he could not see me. I staid there all the time; there could not be more than nineteen sacks delivered at any rate; when he went away, there was a sack of oats lying in the cart, and the others over it - while the men were gone into the public-house, I went to the cart, and saw the oats - they drove the cart, to Mrs. Catharine's, in London-mews. I saw it stop there and turn round. I do not think they saw me at all.

WILLIAM BULL
. The prisoner was in my employ. On the 6th of May, I carted ten quarters, or twenty sacks of oats, from St. Andrew's wharf.
JOHN STAPLES. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 10th of May at Mr. Bulls. I said I took him for some oats; he said,
"What oats" - I said,
"Those delivered at Mrs. Catharine's" - he said, he knew no such person. I said,
"Mrs. Catharine, of Howland-mews;" - he said,
"Mrs. Catharine, of London-mews." I then said,
"What oats were they you delivered to her on Thursday;" - he said,
"I brought some oats for her from a waggon in Drury-lane;" that she had commissioned him to do so; I went to Mrs. Catharine's, and Mr. Spurgeon claimed them.

MARY CATHARINE
. I live in London-mews, and am a stable-keeper. I know the prisoner. I bought some oats of him on the 6th of May; between eight and nine o'clock he shot them into a sack of mine; I gave him 12 s., for them - Mr. Spurgeon came afterwards, and got some of them away.
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Confined Two Months .

1042.
THOMAS PAVIOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , 40 lbs. of lead, value 7 s., the goods of the
Dean and Chapter of the Collegiate Church of St. Peter, in Westminster
, and fixed to the said church .
SECOND COUNT, stating it to be fixed to a building.

CHARLES GREEN
. I am a Thames Police surveyor. I met the prisoner on the 20th of May, coming down King-street, Westminster, carrying something weighty in a white cloth under his arm. I asked him where he got it - he said, it was a cistern; I took him to a public-house, and he there said,

"I will tell you the truth; I am employed as a mason's labourer at Poet's-corner, Westminster-abbey, and this was thrown down to me to go and sell it." I left the lead in the house, and took him into custody.

ALEXANDER MITCHEL. I unrolled the lead; it was measured; and we went to the top of the abbey - it corresponded exactly - there was a piece of solder which was cut from the abbey by Scott, and compared with the other which was taken from the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. They were pulling the whole wall down; this was hanging down; I found it, and took it away.
GUILTY . - Aged 22.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1043.
THOMAS THOMPSON
and
WILLIAM WELLINGTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , a copper boiler, value 12 s.; two pieces of iron railing, value 14 s.; an iron bar, value 1 s.; a dresser, value 8 s.; a plate-rack, value 2 s.; a stove, value 14 s.; a cupboard, value 5 s.; three drawers, value 6 s.; a furnace-door, value 1 s., and a brass cock, value 1 s. , the goods of
John Ianson Fyler
,
Thomas Ratcliff Fyler
,
Thomas Champness Fyler
,
George Townsend
, and
George Ramsey Rodd
.
SECOND COUNT, stating them to belong to a person unknown.

JOHN CHATWOOD
. I am a chemist, and live in Gravel-lane; there are some premises next to me belonging to Messrs. Fyler - I had the key for letting the house. On the 24th of March the articles stated in the indictment were all safe; Thompson took possession of the house adjoining; this house is No. 145, and Thompson's is 145 1/2; I was occasionally there, but did not miss any thing till the 24th of April, when I missed the articles stated in the indictment. On Tuesday the 27th I went to Wellington's shop, and saw the copper boiler which had been in the parlour. I saw Wellington there. I found an aperture, four feet high, cut from Thompson's kitchen to the unoccupied house. I went with the warrant to Wellington's shop, and took the copper - it was the same which had been in the parlour; in the room passing through the shop we saw the cupboard, and we found all the articles except the stove - there was no appearance of the doors or windows having been forced. Thompson lives a quarter of a mile from Wellington, who is Thompson's father-in-law.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I am a constable. I went to Thompson's house on the 27th of May, and said,
"I have a warrant to search your house; the next house has been robbed, and the things are suspected to have been carried through your house; he said
"They may be, but I know nothing about it." I went in, and found the aperture very badly nailed up. I was going up stairs, but he said,
"You need not go up, there is no bed; I sleep with my father in Ratcliff-highway." As we were going to Wellington's I said,
"Shall we find the square copper boiler there;" he said,
"I don't think you will." I then said,
"Is it not exposed for sale on your father's counter;" he said,
"My father has a square copper boiler for sale." I went to the house; the copper boiler was on the counter; I asked the price of it; he said 15 s.; I said,

"Of whom did you buy it;" he said he did not know the man. I asked what he gave for it; he said he had bought it some time, and could not say when; Wellington then said, he was not master of his house, but that it had been brought in by somebody

ANN CHATWOOD
. I am the wife of Mr. Chatwood. I saw Thompson going out of the house one night with something like a door or a shutter - he lived at his shop, but went away of an evening.

THOMPSON'S Defence. My father-in-law took this shop for me, where I go in the day-time, but sleep at home. The houses at the back of the premises are in a very dilapidated state, so that any person might get to the back of the house, and commit the robbery.
NOT GUILTY .

1044.
GEORGE DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of April , 70 lbs. of lead, value 8 s., the goods of
Thomas Pars Edwards
, and fixed to his dwelling-house .
SECOND COUNT, stating it to fixed to a building of his.

THOMAS EDWARDS
. I live in Manchester-street, Mary-le-bone. On the 24th of April I heard of some lead having been stolen from a house belonging to my father,
Thomas Pars Edwards
, at No. 96, Great Portland-street
, which had been empty a short time; we went there, and found some lead was stolen from over the back parlour; we compared the lead produced with what was left; it exactly corresponded as far as it went, but there was much more gone.

JOSEPH WAREMAN
. I am a watchman. On the 23d of April, at two o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner with this piece of lead - I called to him - he quickened his pace, and threw it down at the corner of a street - I sprung my rattle, and pursued him.

JAMES PERRY
. I heard the rattle sprung, and assisted in taking the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Paddington. On my return, passing near Portland-chapel, I found this lead laying on the ground; I took it up, and being seen by the watchman, I threw it down and ran away; another piece of lead was found the same night by the watchman - I hope the Court will believe it was so with mine.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

1045.
EDITH PARSONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , four sovereigns, the monies of
William Casey
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear .
NOT GUILTY.

1046.
MARY DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of June , a watch, value 20 s.; a chain, value 1 s.; a seal, value 2 s., and a key, value 1 s., the goods of
William Hutchinson
, from his person .

WILLIAM HUTCHINSON
. I am a carpenter , and live at Battle-bridge. I was going home on the 2d of June, and met the prisoner; she asked me for some beer; we walked on together, and between there and the new bridge I missed my watch; I accused her with it; she denied it; I told her it was no use denying it, for she should not go till an officer came; Brown came up and took her; I found it in her hand.
Prisoner's Defence. He was to have given me 2 s.; he gave me one, and then gave me the watch till he got the other; he was not sober.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Fourteen Days .
Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1047.
JOHN HENRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , a waistcoat, value 6 d.; a pair of trowsers, value 1 s.; a pair of boots, value 1 s., and 108 penny-pieces, the property of
William M'Gee
, from his person .

WILLIAM M'GEE (a blind man ,) I get my living by selling laces about the streets . On the 11th of April I lodged with Carrigan, in George-yard, Whitechapel
- I was only a nightly lodger. I went to bed between 12 and 1 o'clock - there was no person in the room but me, and the man who has just spoken (the prisoner.) I had a pair of trowsers, a waistcoat, a pair of boots, and some penny-pieces in the inside pocket of this waistcoat. I pulled off my clothes, and put the waistcoat between the bed and sacking - the other clothes I left quite careless about the room. I awoke about seven o'clock I believe, to the best of my knowledge - I felt about before I made any alarm, as I could not see, and did not wish to accuse any one wrongfully - I first missed my boots, and then my other things - I have got my property since - the prisoner slept in the same bed with me - I know him by his voice.

MARY CARRIGAN
. I am the wife of
Michael Carrigan
; we live in George-yard, and take in persons to lodge for the night. I remember the poor blind man coming to lodge there on the night of the 10th of April; the prisoner came before the blind man - they both had the same bed. I recollect the prisoner left a porter's knot, because he had no money, as he stated - he was to pay 4 d. for his lodging - the blind man got up about seven o'clock next morning, and said he had been robbed of his clothes and money. The prisoner was gone - I do not know how he went; he had no money the night before, and left the knot as security, but he has never called for it from that time to this.
Prisoner. I never saw this person in my life - Witness. I am sure he is the man.

MARY M'GEE. I am the wife of the blind man - I did not sleep with him on this night, but I know that he slept there; he used the house. He had a pair of trowsers, a waistcoat, and some money. I saw the prisoner with them on the 15th of April, when he was in custody; he had my husband's trowsers on, but nothing else; they were my husband's trowsers - I looked at them, and knew them to be my husband's.
Prisoner. Q. Were there any pieces in the pockets - A. Yes; I put them in myself.

SARAH FRANCIS
. I live at No. 9, Anchor-street, Rosemary-lane. The prisoner came to lodge at my house on the 10th of April, between ten and eleven o'clock; I refused to take him in. He offered a porter's knot. He went away - he said he had been working all the week, and his master would not pay him till Saturday.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM HALL
. The prisoner was given into my charge. The prosecutor's wife came and identified the trowsers; they were taken off, in my presence, in Newgate.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought the trowsers in Petticoat-lane; I am in the habit of buying these things, and translating them for shops. These I bought a month after Christmas, with some other things, which I have at home now.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined Three Months .

1048.
CATHERINE ANN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of May , a bed, value 10 s.; a bolster, value 3 s.; a table, value 3 s.; two chairs, value 1 s.; a saucepan, value 1 s.; a tea-kettle, value 1 s.; a spoon, value 1 d.; a plate, value 1 d.; a tea-board, value 6 d., and a fender, value 1 d., the goods of
Bernard Gready
, in a lodging-room .

ANN GREADY
. My husband's name is Bernard - we live in Vine-street, Westminster
. The prisoner came to lodge with me about the first week in May; she hired the kitchen only, at 3 s. 6 d. a-week. I let her the articles stated in the indictment with the lodging. She left (without giving warning) before the week expired, and took the key away - we got into the room in about two days, and missed these articles, and others; I found them at her lodgings, in Upper Marsh, Marsh-gate. I found her there, and all the property. She walked over the bridge with me, and I sent for Mr. Patmore to take her up.

ELIZABETH WHITE. I am the wife of
Michael White
, and live at Marsh-gate. The prisoner came to lodge with me about three weeks and three days ago; she took an unfurnished garret, by the name of Godfrey, and brought this furniture there.

WILLIAM PATMORE
. I am an officer. Mrs. Gready sent for me to take the prisoner into custody. I have had the property ever since.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Six Months .

1049.
JOSEPH LEE
and
CORNELIUS LYNCH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , a hat, value 9 s., and a cap, value 1 s. , the goods of
Thomas Savage
.

CHARLES SAVAGE
. I live with
Thomas Savage
- he is a hosier , at No. 98, Grafton-street
. On the evening of the 1st of May, about nine o'clock, a woman said two boys had run away with a hat - I saw the two prisoners carrying a hat, and running away together, about fifty yards from the house. I pursued them; they turned round Windmill-street, and dropped the hat - I took them both myself. They denied any knowledge of the hat. I gave them both in charge. We had missed a cap on the same day.

WILLIAM SELLERS
. I am an officer, and took the prisoners, and found this cap on Lynch's head - he had no hat.
LYNCH'S Defence. I met this boy, and asked which was my way, and while we were talking the man came, and seized us. I had not seen the hat. I bought the cap ten days before.
LEE'S Defence. I was walking by the gateway, and the officer seized me.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

LEE -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

LYNCH -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Confined Three Months and
Whipped .

1050.
RICHARD LANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of May , three live tame fowls, price 6 s. , the property of
Joseph Cable
.

JOHN DAVIS
. I am a watchman of Clerkenwell. On the 19th of May, about half-past four o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner with something in a bag under his arm, in Arlington-street - I spoke to him - he threw it down and ran off. I turned my rattle, and my brother watchman brought him back in about five minutes. A dead fowl was in the bag; he had another fowl in his hat, and had dropped one.

JOHN TAYLOR
. I am a watchman of Clerkenwell. I was with Davis, and pursued the prisoner, and overtook him about one hundred yards from Davis - he dropped a dead fowl from under his coat in coming back. I have shown the fowls to the prosecutor, who claims them as his.

JOSEPH CABLE
. I live at No. 5, William-street, Spafields
, about two or three hundred yards from where the prisoner was taken. I kept five fowls in my area - they were all safe at half-past eleven o'clock when I went to bed, but three of them were gone in the morning. The watchman shewed them to me at Hatton-garden, and to the best of my belief they were mine - I swore to them They were all cut on the left wing.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going along the fields, and found a bag with the fowls near it - I took them up, and was going along when that gentleman stopped me.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Two Months .

1051.
THOMAS KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , a silver fork, value 14 s. , the goods of
John Underwood
.

THOMAS SPARROW
. I live with Mr.
John Underwood
, in Gloucester-place
. I was acquainted with the prisoner; he was out of place, and called on me on Saturday, the 29th of May, about three o'clock - I asked him down stairs, and took him into the pantry; he remained there about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes, and then went away. The plate was in the pantry, and about three hours after he was gone I missed a large fish fork; I had seen it in the morning. I made enquiry, and reported it to my master. I saw it on the Wednesday following.

ROBERT MARCHANT
. I keep a silversmith's shop, in Mortimer-street, Cavendish-square. The prisoner came to me on the Saturday, and asked if I bought old silver - he laid down on the counter a fork, broken in two pieces; I said,
"I can't buy this, it has got a crest upon it, and is almost a new one;" he said,
"Give it to me again" - I said,
"No, I can't, I must send for an officer, and secure you." There were two gentlemen in the shop, and I begged of them to detain him till I got an officer.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM SELLERS
. I am an officer, and took him in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Confined One Year .

1052.
CHARLES BRITTON
and
HENRY SCOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , twenty-eight yards of printed cotton, value 17 s. , the goods of
James Hodgson
,

GEORGE ELLIS
. I am an officer. On the 31st of May, I was in Mile-end-road, about nine o'clock in the evening, and met the prisoners coming across the road - I am certain they were in company. Britton had a bundle under his arm - I asked what he had; he said some printed cotton; that he picked it up at the back of the London Hospital. I took him into custody, and Scott attempted to escape - I told my brother officer to stop him.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. As soon as you saw Britton, and asked what he had got, he said cotton - A. Yes; he never attempted to conceal it.

HENRY POULSON
. I took Scott into custody.

JAMES HODGSON
. I live at Shadwell, and am a linen-draper. The officer showed me this cotton on Tuesday last, the 1st of June, and I knew it immediately; we had not sold but half a yard of it. I had seen it on Monday.
NOT GUILTY .

1053.
ALICE BOWSER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of May , three sheets, value 10 s. , the goods of
William Cruikshanks
.

JOHN OLIVER
. I am a plasterer, and live in Samuel-street
, at Mr.
William Cruikshanks
'; on the 13th of May, while I was in the right-hand room, on the first floor, I heard a noise, and I went out, but saw no one; but I saw wet foot-steps upon the staircase. I opened the window, and saw the prisoner going out of the house. I went down and informed Mrs. Cruikshanks; she pursued her, and took her - I saw her taken; she had some sheets in her apron. I heard her say,
"Take the sheets, and let me go."

ESTHER CRUIKSHANKS. I am the wife of
William Cruikshanks
; I know nothing of the prisoner; Oliver gave me information, and I went out and saw the prisoner about one hundred yards from my house. I found three sheets in her apron - she said,
"Take the sheets, and let me go;" they were my property, she had no business in my house; they had been in the left-hand room on the first floor.

FRANCIS JACKSON
. I have the property.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. As I was passing by, I saw a person drop a bundle; I picked it up, and walked on with it.
GUILTY - Aged 33.
Transported for Seven Years .

1054.
ABRAHAM ABRAHAMS
and
BARNARD ABRAHAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May, seven shillings and three sixpences , the property of
Thomas Welch
.

ANN WELCH
. My husband's name is Thomas - he keeps a van, cart and horse . I keep a shop on Clerkenwell-green
; on the 31st of May, about ten minutes after two o'clock, I went across the green to call my little girl in; when I returned, the prisoners were on the sill of the door;
Abraham Abrahams
asked for an ounce of returns - I went into the shop rather quick, and found 8 s. 6 d., or 9 s., which I had left on the parlour table behind the shop, was gone. I had been gone about a minute and a half, and left no one in my shop but my little boy, who is seven years old. I think it was six or seven shillings, and the rest sixpences, and about 3 s. 6 d. in copper besides; the money wasloose; I had been giving change for a sovereign -
Abraham Abrahams
gave me 6 d. in payment for the tobacco - I went in, and got the three-halfpence, and detained them till my husband came. I then got two officers, who took them into custody; they were searched at the door.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How long were you gone - A. Not more than a minute or a minute and a half; I only went as far as the coach-stand; I could not keep my eye upon the door all the while; my back was turned towards it, and there was time for them to go into my shop and come back to the sill of my door. I am certain no one else went in; there was not time for it. I have no doubt the prisoners had intended to go; but they did not make any attempt to run away. I believe the officer said, one of them had got 1 s. 6 d. in his pocket; I saw them moving as if they had been in, and they were standing on the sill of the door - I did tell the officer there was 12 s. 6 d. on the table; but there was that sum, with the halfpence and all; the halfpence were not touched. I can swear that the silver was from 8 s. 6 d. to 9 s. 6 d. I am certain there was not 10 s., because I had given change for a sovereign. A man and his wife and four children occupy my first floor - I am certain they did not come down - they were at dinner.

- WELCH. I am seven years old - (this witness perfectly undertood the obligation of an oath.) I recollect my mother going out; she was gone but a short time; these men (the prisoners) came to the shop - I was at the door, but they did not speak to me - the one with a black hat on went into the room for about a minute, and then came to the other - my mother came directly afterwards, and then he asked for some returns. I had seen the money on the table. I had been at home all the while my mother was out, and nobody else came in but these men.

Cross-examined. Q. Your mother came home, and these boys were taken up, and you did not say anything about it for a long while after - A. My mother went to Hatton-garden before I did; I went there last Saturday.
Q. You did not tell your mother when she came home,
"Mother, these boys have been taking your money;" - A. No. I do not know why; I said nothing till I heard her say,
"These boys have been robbing me;" - it was about two o'clock.
COURT. Q. When your mother came home, and asked you about it, did you tell the same story as you do now - A. Yes; and went to the office, and told the same story.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I am an officer. I was sent for to Welch's house - the prosecutrix came and fetched me; we found two or three hundred people there; Barnett had a white hat on, and the other a black one - they were charged with stealing some silver. I took them into the parlour - one of them said,

"Don't expose us;" - A. Abrahams sat down on a chair, and he had some tobacco in his hand - I saw his hand in his pocket, and found seven shillings, three sixpences, and three halfpence in his breeches pocket. Thompson asked him where he got it - he was going to say, but the other checked him. I took them to the office.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you search the other prisoner - A. Yes; and found on him a sovereign and some silver; he said it was his own money; I gave it him back again. Mrs. Welch said as we came along, that there were nine or ten shillings; she was in a flurry; this little boy said nothing about it in my presence - I don't think I saw him. I knew nothing of it until they had two examinations at Hatton-garden; the boy was not present until the second time; he was not taken at first because he had not said that he knew anything about it.

ABRAHAM ABRAHAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

BARNARD ABRAHAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined One Year .

1055.
SARAH BLAKELEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of June , a coat, value 4 s., and a gown, value 2 s. , the goods of
Thomas Miller
.

THOMAS MILLER
. I am a pawnbroker , and live in Golden-lane; I have known the prisoner about a fortnight; she was in the habit of pawning things - on the 5th of June, while at dinner, a coat was brought to me by a woman - I thought I knew it, and asked her how she came by it - she said, she was sent by a woman at the public-house. I said,
"I think this is stolen; you stop here, and I will go and find the woman." I went into the tap-room, and picked out the prisoner. I knew it to be mine.
NOT GUILTY .

1056.
SARAH FOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of May , three sheets, value 7 s.; four yards of diaper, value 2 s.; a table-cloth, value 2 s., and a decanter, value 2 s., the goods of
Charles Taylor
, in a lodging-room .

ELIZABETH TAYLOR
. My husband's name is Charles - we live in Narrow-street, Limehouse
. At the latter end of March I let the prisoner a lodging, at 6 s. a-week - she said she had a husband coming from sea - he came that night, and continued with her about three week - she quitted on the 20th of May without warning - after her husband went away she did not pay - he had left her the week after Easter - she owed for about five weeks - she said she had money from her husband monthly, and when she received her money she would pay me - the room had been locked before, but her husband burst the door open - when she went away she left it locked, and took the key - we forced the door open, and missed the articles stated in the indictment, which I have not seen since - they were in the room after her husband left - I did not see her again till about a fortnight after, when I took her at Limehouse - my husband accused her of robbing the room - she said the things were at the washer-woman's in King-street, and she would get them - I went there, but they were pawned.

WILLIAM BROCKWELL
. I am shopman to Mr. Nicholas, a pawnbroker. I have two sheets, and a remnant of diaper, which I took in pawn from the prisoner, and a shirt, which another woman brought.

LOWTHER JACKSON
. I live with Mr. Dickens, a pawnbroker. I have a sheet pawned by a woman (not the prisoner) on the 3d of May, for 2 s.

HANNAH SOUTH
. I am the wife of
Francis South
- the prisoner lodged in my house - she gave me no money, but left me some duplicates, which I gave to the officer.

JOSEPH ADAMS
. I am night beadle of St. Ann's - South gave me the duplicates of the property produced.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 28.

1057.
SARAH FOX
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of December , two sheets, value 4 s.; a blanket, value 3 s., and a caddy, value 2 s., the goods of
Thomas Richard Read
, in a lodging-room .

MARY READ
. I am the wife of
Thomas Richard Read
, who is a shoemaker , and lives in Colt-street, Limehouse
- the prisoner took a furnished room of us about the end of August or beginning of September, and continued till December - she said she had a husband, but he was not with her - she was to pay 4 s. a week - she left in December, without giving warning - she owed 1 l. 5 s. 6 d. - she left the room locked we broke it open, and missed these articles - they were produced by the pawnbroker before the Magistrate.

LOWTHER JACKSON
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce two sheets and a tea-caddy, pawned by the prisoner in the name of Smith, on the 8th of October, 20th of November, and the 24th of December. I am certain of her person.

THOMAS ADAMS
. The prosecutrix gave me the duplicates of this property on Thursday.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. She has had the tickets these four months; and when she found the other woman was bringing an action, then she brought her action.

MARY READ
re-examined. Q. Did you ever summon the prisoner to the Court of Requests - A. No; we summoned the man, not her, some money has been paid.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

1058.
THOMAS CARR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , 15 brass tubes, value 7 s.; 26 brass collars, value 1 s., and 43 brass rings, value 3 s. , the goods of
Thomas Brant
, his master .

THOMAS BRANT
. I am a patent lamp manufacturer , and live in Charles-street, Hatton-garden. The prisoner was my weekly servant ; in consequence of some information, I went with a publican, named Ranwell, to the prisoner's lodgings, to ascertain whether he had got a pint pot - he had given leave for us to go - the officer, who was with us, could not find the pot, but in the cupboard we found some brass goods, which I knew to be my property - when the officer asked how he came to take them, he said he did not know, and said they were his master's; they are worth about 11 s. - he has lived with me six or seven years, and I thought him honest.

WILLIAM LEE
. I am an officer - the last witness's statement is correct; the prisoner asked his forgiveness.
Prisoner's Defence. The were not for myself, but for another person.
GUILTY. Aged 26.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and the Prosecutor .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1059.
MARY COLVIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of June , 20 yards of ribbon, value 14 s., the goods of
Thomas Rees
, privately in his shop .

RALPH ELDRIDGE
. I am shopman to Mr.
Thomas Rees
, linendraper , Shoreditch
. The prisoner came to our shop on Saturday evening last, about eight o'clock, and asked to look at some ribbons - I showed her some - she said she wanted narrow white ribbon - I placed the drawer on the counter, and she ordered one yard and a half of one, and two yards of another, to be cut off - she had not asked any price, which made me suspect she had taken some - there was another person in the shop, at a distance - I turned my head, and when I looked round I missed one of the ribbons, and charged her with it - she immediately pulled a piece from her pocket - I think I had said,
"You have got a piece of ribbon in your pocket;" she had not gone from the shop - I then said,

"How many more have you got;" she was putting her hand again to her pocket, and I got over the counter and took her to the end of the shop - she said she had laid two half-crowns on the counter - it is very unusual for women to come into a shop and take ribbons without asking the price - no other person served her - I saw her come in; and as soon as I took her to the end of the shop, she said she had put two half-crowns on the counter, which I had not seen before - I went and found one on the counter, and one in the drawer.

JOSHUA ARMSTRONG
. I was sent for, and when I came the prisoner said there were two half-crowns on the counter, which she had put down to pay for the ribbons.

BARNARD LEE
. I was with
Joshua Armstrong
- these two pieces of ribbon were taken from the pocket of the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to the shop to buy one yard and a half of ribbon at 3 1/2 d. per yard, and two yards at 5 d. - I asked for some other - he laid hold of me, and shook my hand, and said I was going to steal the ribbon - one gentleman came in with one half-crown, and said it does not belong to her, it belongs to somebody else - I said I had given two half-crowns, and the officer sent him to look for the other, which he found.

RALPH ELDRIDGE
re-examined. Q. Had the prisoner the two pieces of ribbon in her pocket - A. Yes, both of them, she had not tendered any money.
NOT GUILTY .

1060.
JAMES WILD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January , a sovereign and two half crowns , the monies of
James Hulme
, to whom he was servant .
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

JAMES HULME. I am a pawnbroker , and live in Museum-street, Bloomsbury
; the prisoner has been employed by me for three years, or three years and a-half - 1 l. 5 s. had been paid on account of a pledge by a customer; it was in the window, with a note describing what it was, and what it was paid for - it was there in January last - I missed in on Saturday the 10th of January, and spoke to him and the other servant on the subject - I asked where the money was - he said he knew nothing about it - I told him there was nobody in the shop but him and his fellow apprentice , and insisted upon their finding it - the prisoner then pretended to look for it - the other went out of the shop, and then the prisoner said he had taken it - I had not threatened him about it - I asked him how he had disposed of it - he said he had given some to his father and mother, and spent four shillings for me, and spent the rest himself - he had been at Guildhall, and had come home very much intoxicated - he at first denied it - he then went up stairs - I went up and related it in the hearing ofCharles Perry, the other apprentice - he then wanted to go home to his friends - I said,

"No, you shall not go home." I went to clean myself, and he went and got his clothes on, and slipped out at the side door - I have not seen him since, till he was in custody - my other apprentice has likewise run away.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. Did Mr. Harmer come to you on Thursday, the 18th of February, after the officer had been in pursuit of the prisoner, and could not find him - A. Yes; Mr. Harmer said whenever I filed a bill of indictment against him he would come forward - this was when I went to Bow-street; before I had been there previous to that - I saw Mr. Harmer there a second time, and then he told me the same thing, and said he surrender him.
Q. When did you file your bill against him - A. Not till last Sessions, on account of the absence of a material witness.
Q. Is your material witness here to-day - A. No - I had a premium of 40 l. with the prisoner.
Q. Had you a trial at Guildhall - A. Yes; he was there.
Q. Now, upon your oath, do you not know that he expended his money in paying the expences of the witnesses - A. No.

Q. Do you mean to say that you did not know from Mr. Cartridge that he paid part of his expences - A. The witnesses were at England's eating-house - I paid when I was there, and I paid him what he told me he laid out.

Q. What did you pay him - A. I can tell by my book - the first day he was there was on the 5th of January, and I asked him if he had money enough to pay for his dinner - he said he had. On the Tuesday I paid 5 s. 10 d., and 11 d. on Wednesday - and Thursday he said he had laid out a half-a-crown - on the 10th I paid him 4 s. - I had sometimes five witnesses there - I paid the dinners when I was there.
Q. Now, Sir, on your solemn oath, when he told you he had taken the 1 l. 5 s., did he not tell you he had paid the expences with it - A. No - I knew nothing at all about his paying the witnesses.
Q. In point of fact did you not have the 1 l. 5 s. from his mother - A. No, never - I have never received it.

Q. Was any thing ever given to
Charles Perry
at the door - A. Yes; on Monday, as the prisoner went away on the Saturday, while
Charles Perry
was shutting up the shop, he brought in a paper parcel which a man gave him to give me, and he opened the paper in part, and I saw it was the paper that had been in my window - and I said,

"Put it away, seal it up, and put it in the box." When we went down to the Magistrate he would not go into the case, and Perry either took away or lost the key. I cannot open the box; it is here - I do not know what is in it; I cannot open it.

Q. Now, I ask you, at the time Perry received it, and brought it into the shop, if he did not tell you that Wild's mother had sent the money - A. No; I have not to the present moment the least notion of what is in the box.
COURT. Q. Did you see Perry put the paper into the box - A. Yes; but I do not know what was in it - I cannot open it - Perry took the key, and I have not seen it since.

Mr. ALLEY. Q. When did the prisoner tell you he had taken the property - A. On the 10th of January; and the paper was sent on the Monday - he had stated that he had given part to his father and part to his mother, and disposed of the rest himself - I did not, upon my solemn oath, give him leave to take my money to pay the witnesses - when I attended at Bow-street to make a complaint, Mr. Harmer undertook to produce him, but he did not bring him till to-day, to my knowledge - he never went before a Magistrate; and finding I could not get Perry, I put it off to this Sessions, in hopes to find him, which I have taken pains to do, but have not succeeded - he ran away on the 1st of April - I did not go to the prisoner's mother and say he should not come back into my service; I do not recollect any thing more than saying I would not have him on the trial any more - I sent a person to his mother, and to call on Mr. Farebrother to say he should not come again on the trial; but I never directly, or indirectly, sent to any of his relations to say I would not take him back into my service.
Prisoner's Defence. I took it to pay the witnesses, and intended to return it on the Monday morning.

THOMAS TODD
. I attended on the trial of Messrs. Hulme and Cross - there were seven witnesses on that trial; I attended ten days. We dined at England's eating-house; Wild paid the expences; he had to pay 8 d. or 1 s. a piece, according to what they had. He paid about five or six days when I was there, and on the other six days I paid for myself, except one day Mr. Hulme was there, and paid for my dinner.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT.
(5th DAY,)
London Cases, Second Jury, Before Mr. Recorder.

1061.
WILLIAM CAMPION
was indicted for
publishing a scandalous, impious, blasphemous, and profane libel, of and concerning the Holy Scriptures, and the Christian Religion .
MESSRS. BOLLAND and BERNARD conducted the prosecution

THOMAS DRUMMOND
. I am a messenger at the Police Office at Bow-street. I know the house No. 84, Fleet-street; the name of
"R. Carlile" is over the door. On the 5th of May I went to that shop, and saw the defendant there; I asked him for the book called

"Paine's Age of Reason" - he was standing at the counter; he turned round, took it off a pile of books, and gave it to me. I put my name on it; here is the book (producing it) he gave me. I wrote my name on it before I parted possession of it. I paid him 4 s. for it, and asked if he would take off anything if I took half-a-dozen of each - I had bought another book as well - he said he would take of 25 per cent.
The libellous matter set out in the indictment was here read from the work.

The prisoner being called upon for his Defence, read an exceeding long one, consisting of a most profane and appalling attack upon the grand doctrines and precepts of Christianity, which of course are highly improper for publication.
GUILTY .

Confined Three Years in Newgate , and
to enter into his own recognizance for his good behaviour for life .

1062.
THOMAS JEFFERY
was indicted for a
like offence .

WILLIAM COUSINS
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I know the house No. 84, Fleet-street, City - the name of
"R. Carlile" is over the door. On the 11th of May I went into the shop, and saw the defendant behind the counter; I asked if he had got
"Paine's Age of Reason;" he said, Yes. I said,
"Let me have it;" he put it into my hands; here it is (producing it) - I put my initials on it before it went out of my possession. I paid 4 s. for it.
COURT. Q. Did there appear to be many books in the shop - A. It appeared to be well supplied with books.
(The Libel was here read.)

MR. FRENCH addressed the Court and Jury on behalf of the defendant, contending that while Unitarians (whose doctrines he considered highly blasphemous) were tolerated, by law, that it was unjust to prosecute persons in the prisoner's situation of life.
GUILTY .

Confined Eighteen Months , and
to enter into his own recognizance of 100 l. for his good behaviour during life .

1063.
JOHN CHRISTOPHER
was
charged by three indictments with publishing certain wicked, scandalous, and blasphemous libels, of and concerning the Holy Scriptures, and the Christian Religion .
To all three of which indictments he pleaded
GUILTY .

Confined Two Months for each offence , and
enter into his own recognizance of 100 l. for his good behaviour during life .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1064.
JAMES PRICE
and
WILLIAM WALKER
were indicted for
conspiracy .
NOT GUILTY .
SIXTH DAY, WEDNESDAY, JUNE 9.
NEW COURT.
London Cases, Before Mr. Recorder.

1065.
RICHARD HASSELL
and
MICHAEL O'CONNER
were indicted for
publishing a certain profane and blasphemous libel, of and concerning the Holy Scriptures, and the Christian Religion .

GEORGE LEADBEATER
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 21st of May, about half-past one o'clock, I went to the shop, No. 84, Fleet-street, City; the name of
"R. Carlile" is over the door. The defendant Hassell was in the shop - I asked him for another book, and then for
"Paine's Age of Reason;" he said he had merely come into the shop to keep it open, as some of the men there had been taken out, and would not serve me with

"The Age of Reason" then; but if I called in an hour or two I should have it, as he had a person coming into the shop who did not care what he served. I left, and returned about half-past three that afternoon, and found both the defendants there. I said to Hassell,
"Can I have it now;" he said,
"What is it;" - I said,
"The Age of Reason."
Q. How long is this shop - A. It is a large double-fronted shop; O'Conner was not more than a yard from Hassell - he spoke quite loud enough to be heard. When I said I wanted

"The Age of Reason," he turned round to a small box kind of a place behind the counter, and brought me two copies, one bound and the other not; the books were further from O'Conner - he brought them to where I was standing; I asked the price - the bound one was 8 s., and the other was 4 s.; I said I would take the unbound one; O'Conner was within a foot of him at this time. I was going to pay Hassell for it - but he pointed to O'Conner, who held out his hand, and took the money and jingled it on the counter. I then asked for
"Palmer's Principles of Nature." Hassell said they had not got a copy in the shop. O'Connor said,
"Oh, yes; we have got one; let him have it."
Cross-examined by MR. FRENCH. Q. Do you know O'Conner - A. From seeing him on that day. I put no question to him, but paid him the money - Hassell referred me to him; and he held out his hand.
Prisoner Hassell. Q. Did O'Conner appear to have any concern in the shop - was he not sitting down reading at the time - A. He was not; he was behind the counter.
Q. For whom did you buy this book - A. I was sent by the Solicitor of the Treasury. I have not read it.
(The Libel was here read.)

Mr. FRENCH addressed the Court on behalf of O'Connor. The Learned Gentleman, after pursuing the same arguments as upon the trial of Jeffery, stated that the defendant, who was a member of the Established Church, was driven by poverty to enter this shop, but that he himself had not published the libel, and that there was no proof of his knowing for what work he was receiving the money. The Learned Gentleman called the following witnesses: -

NATHANIEL BROOKS
. I live at No. 23, Thomas-street, Grosvenor-square, and have known O'Conner for fifteen years - he was a moral, well-disposed young man, and always kept to the Established Church - he has an aged mother entirely dependant upon him.
COURT. Q. What are you - A. I keep a green-grocer's shop - he was abroad for four years, and returned in December - he has always frequented church since his return.
MR. WONTNER. I am keeper of Newgate. I saw O'Conner on Sunday week attending the chapel - his conduct was very proper. I noticed him particularly; he has only been in my custody for two Sundays.
HASSELL'S Defence was of a most blasphemous and revolting nature.

HASSELL -
GUILTY .

Confined Two Years ; and
to enter into his own recognizance of 100 l. for his good behaviour during life .

O'CONNER -
NOT GUILTY .
SEVENTH DAY, THURSDAY, JUNE 10.
NEW COURT.
London Cases, Before Mr. Recorder.

1066.
JAMES CLARK
was indicted for
publishing a wicked, scandalous, and blasphemous libel .

WILLIAM COUSINS
. I am a patrol of Bow-street; on the 17th of May I went to the shop, No. 84, Fleet-street - the name of
"R. Carlile" is over the door. I saw the defendant, and asked him for No. 17 of

"The Republican;" he handed to me a number, which I produce. I am not certain where he took it from. I asked him the price - he said sixpence, which I paid him. I am certain that this is is the number I bought of him. I marked it before I parted with possession of it - no other person was serving in the shop.

Prisoner. Q. There was another person in the shop - A. I did not notice any other person. I was employed to buy this pamphlet by
George Maule
, Esq., Solicitor to the Treasury - we take our orders either from him or his clerk - I received the order from Mr. Raven, in Mr. Maule's presence.
Prisoner. Q. Did you ask me for any other book - A. Yes, for
"Paine's Age of Reason," and
"Palmer's Principles of Nature;" you said you had none in the shop, but you should have them in two or three days, or a day or two, and should be happy to serve them.

MR.
HENRY BALDWIN RAVEN
(a witness for the prosecution, but not examined by the Learned Counsel.)
Prisoner. Q. Pray, did you read No. 17 of
"The Republican
"before you employed that person to purchase it - A. I did.
Q. You consider it an impious and blasphemous book - A. Most assuredly.
Q. Pray, what do you mean by blasphemy. - A. Any publication which has a tendency to vilify the Bible, the Christian Religion, or our Lord Jesus Christ.
(The Libel was here read.)

The prisoner made a defence which lasted nearly five hours, in which he ridiculed most of the prophecies and miracles contained in the Holy Scriptures, and made the most indecent and shocking reflections upon the characters of the Prophets and Apostles.
GUILTY .

Confined Three Years , and
to enter into his own recognizance for good behaviour during his life, in the sum of 100 l.
EIGHTH DAY, FRIDAY, JUNE 11.
NEW COURT.
London Cases, Before Mr. Recorder.

1067.
WILLIAM COCHRANE
was indicted for
publishing a certain wicked, impious, and blasphemous libel .

GEORGE LEADBEATER
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I know the shop, No. 84, Fleet-street; the name of

"R. Carlile" is over the door. I was directed by a person in the office of the Solicitor of the Treasury, to go to that shop on the 20th of May - I went, but did not see the defendant then - I went again on the 27th, and saw him then - he was standing behind the counter - I asked him for the last number of

"The Republican," which had been published on the Friday preceding (this was on Thursday.) I asked him for the work - he said it was prohibited - I then said I had been there a day or two before, and the answer they gave me was, that they would send it to my address, (which was true but I did not see him then) - he said,
"Oh, very well, then you shall have it;" he went and brought me this number (producing it) - I paid him 6 d. for it, and marked it before it went out of my possession.
COURT. Q. Was any other person serving in the shop at the time he delivered it to you - A. None.

Q. Did he take it from the counter, or where - A. To the best of my recollection there had been a small partition made in this shop a few days before, and he went behind that partition and brought it from there.
(The Libel was here read.)

MR. FRENCH addressed the Court on behalf of the defendant, to the same purport as on the former trials, and wished particularly to press upon them the reluctance evinced to sell the publication in question.
GUILTY .

Confined Six Months , and
to enter into his own recognizance of 100 l. for his good behaviour during life .

1068.
WILLIAM HALEY
was indicted for a
like offence .

GEORGE LEADBEATER
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 22d of May I went to the shop, No. 84, Fleet-street, City; the name of

"R. Carlile" is over the door - having received instructions from persons in the office of the Solicitor of to Treasury - it was between eight and nine o'clock in the morning - I saw the defendant in the shop - he was alone, standing behind the counter - I went in and inquired for the last number of

"The Republican" - he took it from a small place behind the counter, and gave it to me - this is the pamphlet (producing it) - I paid him 6 d. for it - I marked it before it went out of my possession - I have put my initials, and the date on which I bought it, on it.
Prisoner. Q. Do you remember asking me for any thing else - A. No.
Q. On your oath - be particular - A. Yes, I did; I asked for
"The Moralist."
Q. Previous to asking for that, do you remember entering the shop and asking for
"Paine's Age of Reason," or
"Palmer's Principles of Nature." - A. On my oath I did not.

Q. On your oath, did you not say I need not be afraid, for you were going into the country - A. I did not, on my oath - I know that you knew me - you asked how a person belonging to our office was, and said you owed him 3 s., and told me to tell him you would call in the evening and pay him; and said,
"I shall, perhaps, be able then to put you or him into some information that you are not aware of."

Q. Do you remember the reply you made - A. The reply I made was for you not to tell the person you spoke of that I had been there buying this work - I said I did not think I should see him till late that night.
Q. May I ask if you are paid any thing - A. I have not been paid anything; I shall apply for my expences.
(The Libel was here read.)
The defendant, in his defence, pursued the same course as the persons indicted before for like offences.
GUILTY .

Confined Three Years , and
to enter into his own recognizance for his good behaviour during life, in the sum of 100 l.

1069. The said
MICHAEL O'CONNER
was indicted for
publishing a wicked, blasphemous, and scandalous libel, and concerning the Holy Scriptures, and the Christian Religion .
The prisoner pleaded
GUILTY .
Judgment Respited .
NOTE.

On the 5th day of the Session,
John Bailey alias Donald M'Craw
, convicted at the April Session (see pages 250 and 252) was brought to the bar, when Mr. Justice Bayley stated that his case had undergone a full consideration by the Twelve Judges, who were of opinion that the house was properly described as the dwelling-house of
Richard Ryan
; for although the staircase window, at which he was supposed to have entered, was common both to Mr. Ryan and Mr. Choice, yet he had broken into a shop which was part of the house in the sole occupation of Ryan. The prisoner, accordingly, received sentence of
DEATH with the other capital convicts.

The Learned Judge also delivered the decision in the case of
James Walsh
- (See January Sessions, page 140) - which was that the felony was complete, as the property was entirely removed from the place on which it stood. The prisoner was sentenced to be
Transported for the term of Seven Years .
